The Inverse Exponential distribution

Source: R/dist_inverse_exponential.R
dist_inverse_exponential.Rd

dist_inverse_exponential(rate)

Arguments

rate

an alternative way to specify the scale.

See also

actuar::InverseExponential

Examples

dist <- dist_inverse_exponential(rate = 1:5)
dist
#> <distribution[5]>
#> [1] InvExp(1) InvExp(2) InvExp(3) InvExp(4) InvExp(5)

mean(dist)
#> [1] NA NA NA NA NA
variance(dist)
#> [1] NA NA NA NA NA
support(dist)
#> <support_region[5]>
#> [1] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf]
generate(dist, 10)
#> [[1]]
#>  [1] 0.2897595 0.2653536 0.8474281 3.9528604 1.1685550 0.4141122 0.4967014
#>  [8] 0.7759085 3.1919943 0.8967606
#> 
#> [[2]]
#>  [1]  3.8339796  0.1680344  0.8906296  0.5648005  0.4657615  0.9853605
#>  [7]  1.0899852  1.3373649 96.9933985  1.1333761
#> 
#> [[3]]
#>  [1] 0.4651801 0.3531734 0.1759543 0.3822572 0.4615472 0.5672500 1.9050009
#>  [8] 0.4314065 0.1147847 2.8717743
#> 
#> [[4]]
#>  [1] 2.91345957 0.65406593 0.07173402 0.18054353 8.36815883 0.33564592
#>  [7] 0.54855114 0.04929981 1.11260866 0.45468576
#> 
#> [[5]]
#>  [1] 2.53058867 0.16674861 0.15715327 0.05812886 0.23153214 0.15891472
#>  [7] 0.29639883 0.17107693 0.12844786 0.15337902
#> 

density(dist, 2)
#> [1] 0.15163266 0.09735010 0.07054014 0.05515606 0.04524187
density(dist, 2, log = TRUE)
#> [1] -1.886294 -2.329442 -2.651573 -2.897589 -3.095732

cdf(dist, 4)
#> [1] 0.7788008 0.8824969 0.9200444 0.9394131 0.9512294

quantile(dist, 0.7)
#> [1] 2.8036733 1.4018366 0.9345578 0.7009183 0.5607347
